1. **Main Subject/Focus:** The focus is a list of CAD layers, demonstrating a hierarchical naming convention.  The visible portion shows several layers seemingly related to "Electrical" elements, indicated by the repeated prefix "E".

The context mentions a "Design Work Group" contributing to the standard; this screenshot could be from an example drawing or a section of the standard itself illustrating best practices.

The cropped nature of the image suggests a longer list, reinforcing the importance of a clear system for managing a potentially large number of layers in complex CAD drawings. The repetition of "E" suggests a discipline-specific prefix (Electrical), which is a common practice in CAD to categorize layers by engineering discipline (e.g., "A" for Architectural, "S" for Structural, etc.).

CP 83 Part 1: 2004 (2015) is a Singaporean Code of Practice for construction documentation, specifically focusing on the organization and layering of information within digital models.  Developed by the Technical Committee on Construction Industry IT Standards, it defines a standardized format for layer names, encompassing elements like originator, classification, presentation, and status.  The document includes clauses outlining scope, purpose, definitions, and concepts, along with illustrative examples and annexes listing main and sub-elements.  Tables within the code detail the specific codes used for each field within the layer name structure.  This standardization aims to improve interoperability and information exchange within the AEC industry in Singapore.

elements.text: Contents
elements.summary: This document outlines the contents of CP 83: Part 1: 2004 (2015), a Singaporean Code of Practice for construction documentation.  It focuses on the concepts, format, and codes used, providing clauses on scope, purpose, and definitions.  The document includes examples and annexes listing main and recommended sub-elements for construction projects.  Tables detail layer naming conventions, originator codes, element classification, and presentation/status codes.  Figures illustrate the layer name format and structure.  The code was developed by the Technical Committee on Construction Industry IT Standards and references other relevant publications.

Developed by the Technical Committee on Construction Industry IT Standards, CP 83 details layer naming conventions using codes for originator, classification, presentation, and status. elements.summary: CP 83 Part 1: 2004 (2015) is a Singaporean Code of Practice for construction documentation, specifically focusing on layer naming conventions within Computer-Aided Design (CAD).  It defines the scope, purpose, and relevant terms, and provides a structured format using codes for consistent organization of elements within CAD drawings.  The code includes examples and appendices listing main and recommended sub-elements, along with tables outlining the coding system for layer names based on originator, classification, presentation, and status.  This standardized approach aims to improve communication and collaboration within the AEC industry.

elements.text: Current users of CP 83 include architects, professional engineers - C&S and M&E, as well as contractorswho participate in Electronic Submission. The Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) and the BuildingConstruction Authority (BCA) have adopted the CAD layers for Electronic Development Application (EDA)and Electronic Submission System (eSS) respectively.
elements.summary: CP 83, a CAD layering standard, is utilized by architects, civil/structural/M&E engineers, and contractors involved in Electronic Submission.  Both the Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) and Building Construction Authority (BCA) have integrated these CAD layers into their respective electronic submission platforms: EDA (Electronic Development Application) and eSS (Electronic Submission System).

elements.text: CAD vendors have developed software tools that can implement and support CP 83. BCA has beenconducting hands-on training on CP 83 and the software application on various CAD platforms.
elements.summary: Software tools supporting the CP 83 CAD standard have been developed, and the Building Construction Authority (BCA) provides training on CP 83 implementation across various CAD platforms.

elements.text: The revision of CP 83: Part 1 CAD layer names, is required in order to streamline industry practices forbuilding projects as well as infrastructure projects such as the Mass Rapid Transport extensions whichinclude architectural, civil and structural as well as mechanical and electrical works. The revised list ofmain and sub elements gives the users flexibility to combine the main and sub-elements based ontheir requirements.
elements.summary: CP 83: Part 1, which defines CAD layer names, has been revised to streamline workflows for both building and infrastructure projects (e.g., MRT extensions) encompassing architectural, structural, mechanical, and electrical disciplines.  The update provides users greater flexibility in combining main and sub-layer elements to suit project needs.

elements.text: The major changes are as follows:
elements.summary: This text prefaces a detailed list of changes to the Singapore Standard CP 83 Part 1, a code of practice for CAD layering in construction.  Key updates are driven by the need to streamline CAD practices across building and infrastructure projects (including MRT extensions) and accommodate architectural, structural, M&E, and civil works.  The revisions offer greater flexibility in combining main and sub-element layers.  The document also includes standard legal disclaimers regarding patent rights and license usage.

CAD vendors are expected to support this standard through software tools.  The standard applies to all parties involved in CAD documentation, including third-party component library creators.

pages.summary: Singapore Standard CP 83 Part 1: 2004 (2015) defines CAD layering standards for construction documentation in Singapore, aiming to improve communication and project management.  Developed by the Technical Committee on Construction Industry IT Standards, it's used by architects, engineers, and contractors for electronic submissions to government agencies like URA and BCA (via EDA and eSS platforms).  The code specifies a structured naming convention using codes for originator, classification, presentation, and status, offering flexibility in combining main and sub-elements.  Software vendors support this standard, and BCA provides training.  The standard draws upon existing publications and includes patent protections. elements.text: C ode of practice for construction computer-aided design (CAD)Part 1 – Organisation and naming of CAD layers
elements.summary: This Singapore Standard code of practice defines principles for structuring and naming CAD layers within construction project files.  It aims to standardize CAD layer organization and naming across the Singapore construction industry, facilitating communication and management. The standard applies to all stakeholders involved in CAD documentation, including users and software developers, and extends to third-party component libraries.  It provides a standardized list of CAD layer element names.

elements.text: 1 Scope
elements.summary: This excerpt from the Singapore Standard Code of Practice for Construction Computer-Aided Design (CAD) defines the scope of Part 1, focusing on the organization and naming of CAD layers.  It aims to establish consistent layer structure within CAD files for construction projects in Singapore, facilitating communication and management.  The standard applies to all parties involved in creating and using CAD documentation, including users and software developers, and extends to component libraries from third parties.

elements.text: T his Singapore Standard establishes the general principles of layer structure within constructioncomputer-aided design (CAD) files. It covers the organisation and allocation of layers that are used inCAD files for construction projects, and is intended to be used for communication and managementpurposes. A list of standard CAD layer element names is provided in this code.
elements.summary: This Singapore Standard defines principles for organizing and naming layers within construction CAD files, providing a standardized system for communication and management of project data.  It specifies a list of standard CAD layer element names and covers layer organization and allocation for construction projects.

elements.text: T he principles established in this code are applicable to all parties involved in preparing and usingtechnical documentation on CAD systems. Although these principles are primarily for users, CADsystem developers are expected to provide software tools capable of implementing and supporting thiscode. An important use is also to structure data in component libraries produced by third parties.
elements.summary: This section of the Singapore Standard for construction CAD details the applicability of the code.  It emphasizes that while primarily for CAD users, software developers should ensure their systems support the code's implementation, including third-party component libraries.  The code aims to standardize CAD layer organization and naming across all parties involved in construction project documentation.

elements.text: 2 Purpose
elements.summary: The purpose of the Singapore Standard Code of Practice for Construction Computer-Aided Design (CAD) Part 1 is to establish a uniform system for organizing and naming CAD layers within the Singapore construction industry. This standardization aims to improve communication and management of CAD data across all project stakeholders.

elements.text: T he purpose of this code is to establish uniformity in the organisation and naming of CAD layers forthe construction industry in Singapore.
elements.summary: This Singaporean code of practice aims to standardize CAD layer organization and naming within the construction industry, promoting consistent practices for improved communication and management of CAD data.

elements.text: 3 Definitions
elements.summary: This section of the Singapore Standard defines key terms related to CAD layering.  It defines "Layer" as an organizational attribute in CAD files used for data separation, management, communication, and visibility control, noting that synonyms like "level" may be used.  It also indicates that a definition for "CAD model" will follow.

elements.text: F or the purposes of this code, the following definitions shall apply.
elements.summary: This section of the Singapore Standard specifies that the definitions provided within the standard document will be used for interpreting and applying the code related to CAD layer structuring.  In other words, the document establishes its own internal glossary of terms for clarity and consistency.

elements.text: 3 .1 Layer
elements.summary: This excerpt defines a "Layer" within Computer-Aided Design (CAD) systems for the Singapore construction industry.  A layer is an organizational tool for CAD data, managing, communicating, and controlling the visibility of entities both on-screen and in printed drawings.  The term "layer" may also be referred to as "level" in some CAD software.

elements.text: O rganisational attribute of entities in CAD files, used to separate data in order to manage andcommunicate those data, to control visibility on the computer screen and on plotted drawings.
elements.summary: This excerpt defines a CAD layer as an organizational tool within CAD files.  Layers separate data for management, communication, and control of visibility both on-screen and in printed drawings.  It also notes that other terms, like "level," may be used synonymously with "layer" in various CAD systems.

elements.text: N OTE – In CAD systems, synonyms for “layer” are used, for example “level.”
elements.summary: Some CAD systems use synonyms for "layer," such as "level."  This is important to note given the code's goal of standardizing CAD layer organization and naming.

elements.text: 3 .2 CAD model
elements.summary: A CAD model is a structured CAD file organized according to the physical parts of the object it represents (e.g., a building or mechanical device).  Models can be 2D or 3D and contain both graphical and non-graphical data.

elements.text: S tructured CAD data file(s) organised according to the physical parts of the objects represented, forexample, a building or a mechanical device.
elements.summary: CAD data files are structured and organized based on the physical components of the represented objects, such as buildings or mechanical devices.

elements.text: N OTE – Models can be two-dimensional or three-dimensional, and can include graphical as well as non-graphical data attached to the objects.
elements.summary: CAD models can be 2D or 3D, containing both graphical and non-graphical data linked to the model's objects.  This expands on the prior definitions of CAD model, drawing, and plot, clarifying that models are not limited to visual representation.

elements.text: 3 .3 CAD drawing
elements.summary: A CAD drawing (3.3) is a selected portion of a CAD model, displayed on screen or paper.  Visibility is controlled through views and layers.  Drawings may include additional graphics like borderlines and title blocks, and can be created with or without an underlying CAD model (drawing-oriented vs. model-oriented approach).

elements.text: S elected parts of a CAD model as presented on screen or on paper.
elements.summary: A CAD view shows selected portions of a CAD model, displayed either on screen or as a printed output.

elements.text: N OTE – Visibility on the drawing can be controlled by views and layers. The drawing can contain additionalgraphics, such as borderlines, title-block and legends. CAD drawings can also be produced independentlywithout an underlying CAD model (a drawing-oriented approach as opposed to the model-oriented approach).
elements.summary: CAD drawings display selected portions of a CAD model, potentially with added graphics like borders and title blocks.  Visibility within the drawing is managed through views and layers.  While typically derived from a CAD model (model-oriented approach), drawings can also be created independently without a model (drawing-oriented approach).

elements.text: 3 .4 Plot
elements.summary: Given the provided context of CAD models, drawings, and related terms, the single term "3.4 Plot" likely refers to a hardcopy or electronic output of a CAD drawing, generated from either a 2D or 3D model or a drawing-oriented file.  This output could be to various media (paper or electronic) and would represent the information specified by chosen views, layers, and potentially additional graphical elements like title blocks and legends.

elements.text: G raphic image created by a numerically controlled draughting machine and presented on draughtingmedia.
elements.summary: A plot is a graphic image created by a numerically controlled drafting machine and presented on a drafting medium.  This relates to the broader context of CAD models and drawings, which can be 2D or 3D, and may exist with or without underlying model data.

pages.summary: This document details the Singapore Standard Code of Practice for Construction Computer-Aided Design (CAD) Part 1, specifically focusing on CAD layer organization and naming.  It establishes a standardized system for structuring and naming CAD layers within construction project files to improve communication and data management across all stakeholders, including CAD users, software developers, and third-party component library providers.  The standard defines key terms like "Layer" (an organizational attribute for managing CAD data visibility) and "CAD Model" (a structured file representing the physical parts of an object).  It also distinguishes between "CAD Drawing" (a selected portion of a model displayed on screen or paper) and "Plot" (a hardcopy or electronic output of a drawing).  Chang Kuo Wei of CH2M HILL Singapore Pte Ltd holds a single-user license for this standard, which prohibits copying and networking.

elements.summary: This excerpt from CP 83: Part 1: 2004 (2015) defines several terms related to CAD drawings and layering.  It clarifies that a CAD drawing (3.3) can be a view of a model or a standalone drawing, potentially including standard elements like title blocks and legends.  A plot (3.4) is defined as a physical output from a plotter.  A wildcard (3.5) is explained as a character used for string comparisons. Finally, it introduces the concept of layer name sub-classification (3.6) with the example of "Originator" (3.6.1) as one such classification.  The standard emphasizes that each classification within a layer name is independent.

elements.text: 3.5 Wildcard
elements.summary: A wildcard is a special character used in string comparisons to match any character or group of characters.  This is relevant in the context of CAD drawings and models, potentially for searching or filtering layers, file names, or other text-based data.

elements.text: A special character used to match any character or group of characters in a string comparison.
elements.summary: Wildcards are special characters used in string comparisons to represent any character or group of characters.  This allows for flexible searching and filtering within CAD software.

elements.text: 3 .6 Layer name sub-classification
elements.summary: The text defines the sub-classification of CAD layer names, using independent classifications for originator (individual/company/organization responsible for the layer's creation) and element (a two-level classification of construction work/system with main element and sub-element).

elements.text: T he following concepts are used in the layer name. An independent classification can be applied toeach concept.
elements.summary: CAD layer names utilize independent classifications for each of the following concepts: Originator (individual/company creating the layer), Element (two-level classification of construction work/system with main and sub-elements), and Wildcard (special character for string comparison matching).

elements.text: 3 .6.1 Originator
elements.summary: This section (3.6.1 Originator) of CP 83 Part 1: 2004 (2015) defines the "Originator" within the layer naming convention as the individual, company, or organization responsible for creating and preparing the information on that specific CAD layer.  This contributes to the overall layer name sub-classification system, which allows independent classification for each concept (Originator, Element, etc.).

elements.text: T he originator refers to the individual/company/organisation responsible for preparation and creation ofinformation on the CAD layer.
elements.summary: The "Originator" in a CAD layer name identifies the individual, company, or organization responsible for creating and preparing the information on that layer.

elements.text: 3 .6.2 Element
elements.summary: Section 3.6.2 defines an "Element" within the CAD layer naming convention.  An Element classifies construction work or a system using two sub-classifications: "Main Element" (primary system/work type) and "Sub-element" (specific sub-system within the main element).

elements.text: A n element is a classified construction work or system. It consists of two levels of classifications,namely, main element and sub-element.
elements.summary: Elements within CAD layers are classified construction works or systems, categorized hierarchically into two levels: main element (primary system) and sub-element (secondary system within the main element).

elements.text: 3 .6.3 Main element
elements.summary: Main element is the primary classification level within the "Element" concept used in CAD layer naming. It categorizes the main types of construction work or systems.

elements.text: M ain element is the first level of element classification. It represents the different types of mainconstruction works or systems.
elements.summary: Main elements are the primary classification level for construction works or systems in CAD layering.  They represent the main types of construction work.

elements.text: 3 .6.4 Sub-element
elements.summary: Sub-elements provide a second level of classification within a main element, representing the various sub-systems of that main construction work or system.

elements.text: S ub-element is the second level of element classification. It represents the various sub-systemswithin the main element.
elements.summary: Sub-elements provide a further level of classification within main elements, representing the different sub-systems of a larger construction work or system.  This allows for more granular categorization of elements in CAD drawings.

elements.text: 3 .6.5 Presentation
elements.summary: Presentation in CAD drawings refers to the format and visual appearance of information on screen and paper, distinct from element information which describes the construction work or system itself.

elements.text: P resentation is the format or type of information presented in CAD drawings. It is related primarily tothe graphic appearance on screen and paper, as against element information, which is related toconstruction work or system.
elements.summary: CAD drawing "Presentation" refers to the visual format of information (graphic appearance on screen/paper), distinct from "element information" which describes the actual construction work or system.

elements.text: 3 .6.6 Status
elements.summary: "Status" in AEC documentation, specifically within the context of addition-and-alteration works, defines the condition of an element as being new, retained from existing construction, or slated for demolition.

elements.text: S tatus defines whether the element in addition-and-alteration works is new, for retention or demolition etc.
elements.summary: In CAD drawings for addition and alteration work, the "Status" attribute defines whether an element is new, retained from existing construction, or slated for demolition.

elements.text: 3 .6.7 User-defined
elements.summary: "User-defined" fields provide a flexible way to add further categorization or descriptive information to CAD elements beyond the standard classifications like Sub-element, Presentation, and Status. This allows users to tailor the layering system to their specific needs and workflows.

elements.text: U ser-defined is an additional information field, which the user may wish to use for further subdivisionof layers or provide a description not covered under this Singapore Standard.
elements.summary: User-defined fields in CAD layering provide flexibility beyond the standard classifications outlined in the Singapore Standard, allowing users to add custom subdivisions or descriptions to layers as needed.

elements.text: 4 Concepts, format and codes used in construction documentation
elements.summary: This section of the Singapore Standard outlines the concepts, formats, and codes for CAD layering in construction projects.  Consistent layering facilitates interoperability between different CAD systems and organizations, enabling efficient data exchange and management.  Key aspects include: unique layer names for selective viewing and plotting; a logical layer structure based on information classification; and pre-agreement among project stakeholders on layer selection, codes, and data transfer methods.  This standardized approach supports communication, management, and submission to approving agencies.

elements.text: 4 .1 General
elements.summary: This section (4.1 General) introduces the concepts, format, and codes for CAD layering in construction documentation.  Consistent layer naming conventions are crucial for interoperability between different CAD systems and organizations.  The standard proposes a structured layer naming system with fixed character lengths and reserved codes for consistent identification, selection, and management of CAD data. Project stakeholders should agree on layer usage and data transfer procedures.  Layer names should be both human- and machine-readable.

elements.text: W hen CAD data is transferred between different systems and organisations, their structure needs tobe understood for identification of the source of the CAD data, selection to suit the needs of differentspecialists and management of the data.
elements.summary: When transferring CAD data between different systems and organizations, understanding the data structure is crucial for identifying the source, enabling specialists to select relevant data, and effectively managing the information.  This reinforces the importance of standardized layer naming conventions as described in the preceding context.

elements.text: L ayering is a commonly used technique to achieve such an organisation of CAD data. Layers aregiven unique names so that they can be selectively viewed and plotted. CAD layers need to bestructured based on clear and logical organisation of information that fulfils the functional requirementsof the information users. The organisation of these information can be achieved through the use ofclassifications of information in different parts of the layer name.
elements.summary: CAD data is organized using layers with unique names for selective viewing and plotting.  Effective layering requires a clear, logical structure based on information classification within the layer name to meet user needs.

pages.summary: CP 83: Part 1: 2004 (2015) defines standards for CAD layering in construction projects to ensure interoperability and efficient data exchange.  It details a structured layer naming system with sub-classifications including: "Originator" (individual/company creating the layer), "Element" (hierarchical classification of construction work with "Main Element" and "Sub-element"), "Presentation" (visual format), "Status" (for addition/alteration projects - new, existing, demolished), and "User-defined" fields for added flexibility.  The standard emphasizes consistent layer names, logical structure based on information classification, and pre-agreement among stakeholders on layer usage and data transfer methods.  Key terms defined include "CAD drawing," "plot," and "wildcard."  This standardized approach facilitates selective viewing, plotting, data management, and submission to approving agencies.

elements.text: The following concepts, categories, format and codes shall be used to allocate layers on constructionprojects for the purposes of communication, management and submission to approving agencies. Thoseinvolved in any project shall agree on the selection of the layers and codes to be used and how the datawill be transferred between their CAD systems.
elements.summary: Construction projects shall use agreed-upon concepts, categories, formats, and codes for CAD layering to facilitate communication, management, and submissions.  Project stakeholders must pre-determine layer selection, codes, and CAD data transfer methods. This ensures consistent layer structuring for interoperability and efficient data exchange between different systems.

elements.text: A ll characters used in the layer names shall be both human- and machine-readable whereverpossible. A layer format with fixed number of characters is used to allow selection of layers by the useof wildcard. Where reserved codes are given, they shall be used only for the purpose specified. Otherproject-specific codes may also be used.
elements.summary: Layer names in CAD data exchange should be human- and machine-readable using a fixed-character format for wildcard selection.  Reserved codes must be used as specified, while project-specific codes are permitted.

elements.text: L ayer names are divided into fields. Each field holds one concept. Fields are either mandatory oroptional. Mandatory fields shall always be included in the layer names. Optional fields can be used asrequired in each project. The order of fields in a layer name and the number of characters for eachfield shall be maintained as defined in this code unless an alternative is specifically agreed by theproject partners. However, the alternative adopted shall be documented in a way that future retrievalof the layer-structured information can be ensured.
elements.summary: CAD layer names are structured using mandatory and optional fields, each representing a specific concept.  The defined order and character length of these fields must be maintained unless an alternative, documented for future retrieval, is agreed upon by all project partners.

elements.text: 4 .2 Format of layer name
elements.summary: CAD layer names should follow a structured format for consistent communication and data management across construction projects.  This format consists of five defined fields (Table 1 and Figure 1, not provided in the excerpt) with a fixed number of characters for each, allowing wildcard selection.  While mandatory fields must always be present, optional fields can be used on a project-specific basis.  All project partners must agree upon the selected layers, codes, and data transfer methods.  Any deviations from the standard format must be documented to ensure future information retrieval.  Layer names should be both human- and machine-readable.

elements.text: A layer name consists of the following five fields as shown in Table 1.
elements.summary: This excerpt from the Singapore Standard for CAD layering in construction projects specifies that layer names consist of five fields as detailed in Table 1 (not provided in the given text).  The standard emphasizes consistent structure for interoperability and requires agreement among project partners on layer usage and data exchange. While the standard defines mandatory and optional fields with fixed character lengths, project-specific variations are allowed if documented for future data retrieval.  The arrangement of these five fields is further illustrated in Figure 1 (also not provided).

elements.text: Table 1 – Description of fields in a layer name
elements.summary: The text defines a standardized CAD layer naming convention for AEC projects, emphasizing consistent communication and data exchange.  Layer names use a fixed-length, five-field format (some optional) for machine readability and wildcard selection.  Project teams must agree on layer usage and document any deviations from the standard format described in Table 1.  This ensures future retrieval of layer-structured information.  The table itself (not provided) details the meaning and purpose of each field within the layer name.

elements.text: Figure 1 – Layer name format
elements.summary: CAD layer names are constructed from five fields: originator, element, material, status, and detail.  The format, as shown in Figure 1, uses underscores as separators.  While material, status, and detail are optional, originator and element are mandatory.

elements.text: (NOTE: * - Optional field)
elements.summary: CAD layer names must follow a specific five-field format (as detailed in Table 1 and Figure 1).  The first two fields (originator and element) are mandatory.  Underscores separate fields for readability.  Hyphens fill any unused portions of a field to indicate no further subdivision.  Optional fields are indicated with an asterisk.

elements.text: 4 .3 Coding conventions
elements.summary: CAD layer names should follow a specific five-field format (originator_element_location_type_attribute) where originator and element are mandatory.  Underscores separate fields, hyphens indicate no further subdivision within a field, and allowed characters are A-Z, 0-9, hyphen, and underscore.

elements.text: 4 .3.1 The first two fields, namely originator and element shall always be used.
elements.summary: CAD layer names must always include the "originator" and "element" fields as the first two components.

elements.text: 4 .3.2 The underscore character “_” is used between fields to enhance readability.
elements.summary: Layer names in Figure 1 use a structured format with fields separated by underscores for readability.  The "originator" and "element" fields are mandatory.  Unused trailing characters within mandatory fields and subdivisions are filled with hyphens.  Allowed characters are A-Z, 0-9, hyphen, and underscore. All fields are left-justified.

pages.summary: This excerpt from the Singapore Standard for CAD layering in construction projects defines a strict five-field naming convention (Originator_Element_System/Subsystem_Zone_Detail*) for improved interoperability and data management.  Originator and Element fields are mandatory, while System/Subsystem, Zone, and Detail are optional.  Underscores separate fields, and hyphens fill unused character spaces within a field.  Permitted characters are A-Z, 0-9, hyphen, and underscore.  While the standard promotes consistency using fixed-length fields for each component, project-specific deviations are permissible if documented and agreed upon by all stakeholders.  This documentation is crucial for future data retrieval.  The standard, licensed for single-user access by CH2M HILL SINGAPORE PTE LTD, emphasizes pre-agreement on layer usage and data exchange methods among project partners.  Table 1 and Figure 1 (not provided) further detail the standard's implementation, including specific codes and visual representation of the layer name structure.  A provided screenshot of a CAD layer manager demonstrates the principle of the naming convention, though with simplified, likely placeholder, layer names.

elements.summary: The provided text "CP 83 : Part 1 : 2004 (2015)" refers to a standard (likely a British Standard Code of Practice) defining layer naming conventions in CAD.  The key aspects are: a structured format with mandatory "originator" and "element" fields, followed by optional fields.  Underscores separate fields, hyphens denote no further subdivision within a field and fill unused trailing characters in mandatory fields.  Allowed characters are alphanumeric, hyphens, and underscores.  Fields are left-justified, and unused trailing *optional* fields can be omitted.  The referenced Figure 1 likely visually illustrates this structure.

elements.text: 4.3.3 For indication of no further subdivision of the information, hyphens shall be used to fill out tothe end of the field.
elements.summary: Within the AEC coding convention for layer naming, if a field has no further subdivisions, it must be filled with hyphens ("-") to the end of the field.

elements.text: 4 .3.4 Alphanumeric characters allowed are the letters A - Z, the digits 0 - 9, in addition to thehyphen and underscore characters.
elements.summary: Layer names use alphanumeric characters (A-Z, 0-9), hyphens (-), and underscores (_).

elements.text: 4 .3.5 All fields are left justified.
elements.summary: Layer names are left-justified within their fields.

elements.text: 4 .3.6 Unused trailing characters in a mandatory field shall be represented by the hyphen "-"character.
elements.summary: Within the layer naming convention, any unused trailing characters in a required field must be filled with hyphens ("-").

elements.text: 4 .3.7 Unused trailing fields in optional part of the layer name can be omitted.
elements.summary: Unused trailing fields within the optional portion of CAD layer names (as defined in CP 83 : Part 1 : 2004 (2015)) are not required and can be left out.  This contrasts with mandatory fields which must be filled with hyphens if unused (4.3.6).

elements.text: 4 .4 Layer name fields
elements.summary: Layer names are structured with specific fields.  These fields are left-justified and filled with hyphens (-) for any unused trailing characters within mandatory fields. Optional fields at the end can be omitted entirely.  One key field is the two-character "Originator" field, indicating the discipline responsible for the layer's information (e.g., architecture, structural engineering). The first character is a capital letter abbreviation for the discipline (see Table 2 for codes).

elements.text: 4 .4.1 Originator field
elements.summary: Layer names use a two-character originator field to identify the discipline responsible for the layer's information.  The first character is a capital letter abbreviation (see Table 2) for the discipline.

elements.text: T his field indicates the discipline of an individual/company/organisation responsible for the preparationand creation of information in the CAD layer. Since there is a multitude of possible classifications,depending on the type and organisation of the project at hand, two (2) alphanumeric characters areused for this field.
elements.summary: The "Originator" field in a CAD layer name identifies the discipline responsible for creating the layer's information.  This two-character alphanumeric field accommodates the variety of potential classifications across different project types and organizations.

elements.text: 4 .4.1.1 First character
elements.summary: The first character of the Originator field (a two-character code identifying the discipline responsible for CAD layer information) is a single capital letter abbreviating that discipline.  A table (Table 2) provides a list of standard codes, but additional codes can be used internally within organizations or projects.

elements.text: T his first character is a single alphabet code in capital letter to abbreviate the discipline of theoriginator of the layer. The list of possible originator codes is as shown in Table 2.
elements.summary: The first character of the originator field in a CAD layer name is a single capital letter abbreviating the originator's discipline (e.g., architectural, structural).  A table (Table 2) provides a list of these codes, though additional codes can be used internally within organizations or projects.

elements.text: Table 2 – Codes for originator field
elements.summary: The text excerpt describes the "Originator" field within a CAD layer naming convention. This field, comprised of two alphanumeric characters, identifies the discipline responsible for the layer's creation.  The first character (capital letter) broadly defines the discipline (e.g., 'A' for Architect, 'S' for Structural Engineer), as listed in Table 2.  The second character provides further specification within a discipline (e.g., 'L' in 'AL' for Landscape Architect) or a hyphen '-' if no further specification is needed (e.g., 'A-' or 'S-'). While Table 2 provides a standard list of codes, additional codes can be used internally within organizations or projects.

pages.summary: CP 83 Part 1: 2004 (2015) defines a CAD layer naming convention emphasizing a structured, left-justified format.  Layer names consist of mandatory "originator" and "element" fields, followed by optional fields, separated by underscores.  Mandatory fields must be fully populated; unused trailing characters are filled with hyphens. Optional fields can be omitted.  The two-character "originator" field identifies the discipline responsible for the layer (e.g., 'A-' for Architect, 'AL' for Landscape Architect). The first character is a capital letter abbreviation (defined in Table 2), while the second character allows further subdivision within a discipline or uses a hyphen if no further breakdown is needed.  While Table 2 provides standard codes, organizations can implement custom alphanumeric codes.  Allowed characters in layer names are alphanumeric, hyphens, and underscores.  Figure 1 likely provides a visual representation of this structure.

elements.text: 4.4.1.2 Second character
elements.summary: The second character in the layer naming convention further defines the discipline of the originator.  A hyphen (-) is used if no further definition is needed (e.g., A- for Architect).  Alternatively, it can specify a sub-discipline (e.g., AL for Landscape Architect) or differentiate multiple entities within the same discipline on the same project (e.g., A1 and A2 for two different architects).

elements.text: T he second character provides further definition of the originator whenever necessary. Example: ALto denote Landscape Architect. If the first character is sufficient to define the originator of the layer, ahyphen "-" shall be used as the second character of this field. Example: A- for architect and S- forstructural engineer.
elements.summary: The second character in the originator code provides additional discipline detail when needed (e.g., "AL" for Landscape Architect).  If the first character sufficiently identifies the originator (e.g., "A" for Architect, "S" for Structural Engineer), a hyphen "-" is used as the second character.

elements.text: T his second alphanumeric character can also be used to denote different originators from the samediscipline involved in the same project. Example: A1 and A2 represent two different architects workingon the same project.
elements.summary: The second character of the originator code can differentiate between multiple entities from the same discipline working on the same project. For example, A1 and A2 could represent two different architectural firms.

elements.text: 4 .4.2 Element field
elements.summary: The "Element field" (4.4.2) classifies the construction work or system of elements within a layer using an eight-character code.  This code is divided into two four-character segments: the mandatory "Main element" identifying the primary system and the optional "Sub-element" providing further classification. If no sub-element is needed, it's filled with "----".

elements.text: T his field indicates the type of construction work or system of the element in the layer. Classificationfor the construction elements or systems is in the form of eight (8) letters of the alphabet. Thiselement field has two levels of classification, namely, the main and sub-elements.
elements.summary: This text describes the "element field" used for classifying construction elements or systems within a layer.  This eight-character code uses two four-character sub-fields: a mandatory "main element" and an optional "sub-element".  The main element identifies the primary construction work or system.  The sub-element provides further classification if needed; otherwise, it's filled with hyphens ("----").

elements.text: 4 .4.2.1 Main element
elements.summary: The main element, a mandatory four-letter code, identifies the primary construction work or system of a layer.  It's the first level of classification within the eight-character element field, which may be further defined by a sub-element.

elements.text: T he main element consists of four (4) letters of the alphabet and is mandatory. It identifies the mainconstruction work or system of the element.
elements.summary: Layer names use a two-character originator code. The first character identifies the discipline (e.g., A for Architect, L for Landscape Architect).  If no further distinction is needed, the second character is a hyphen (e.g., A-).  If multiple entities from the same discipline are involved, the second character is a number (e.g., A1, A2).  The element field, an eight-character code, further defines the layer.  The first four characters represent the mandatory main element, identifying the primary construction work or system.  The remaining four characters are the sub-element, providing further classification when needed; otherwise, they are filled with hyphens ("- - - -").

elements.text: 4 .4.2.2 Sub-element
elements.summary: Sub-elements, identified by four letters, provide further classification within a main element.  If no sub-element is needed, four hyphens ("----") are used.

elements.text: T he sub-element consists of four (4) letters of the alphabet and is only used for further classification ofthe main element. For elements where classification using the main element is sufficient, the sub-element may be coded with four (4) hyphen characters "- - - -".
elements.summary: Sub-elements, using four letters, provide further classification within a main element.  If the main element classification is sufficient, the sub-element field should be filled with "----".

elements.text: T able 3 shows some examples of classification in element field.
elements.summary: Table 3 provides examples of how to classify elements using the 8-character code (4 for the main element and 4 for the optional sub-element).  Standard main element names are listed in Annex A, and recommended sub-element names are in Annex B.  While users should adhere to these standards for consistency, custom element codes can be used internally if documented and communicated effectively within the project team.

elements.text: Table 3 – Examples of classification of element field
elements.summary: Table 3 provides examples of how to use the 4-letter code for classifying elements, consisting of a mandatory main element and an optional sub-element.  If no sub-element is needed, it's coded as "----".  Standard main and recommended sub-element names are listed in Annex A and B respectively, and should be used for industry consistency.  User-defined elements are permitted for internal use but must be documented and communicated clearly within the project.  While no strict rules exist for creating abbreviations, a general guideline is to truncate vowels while retaining the first and last characters.

pages.summary: This excerpt from Singapore Standard CP 83: Part 1: 2004 (2015) details a layer naming convention for construction projects.  Layer names utilize a two-character originator code (e.g., A- for Architect, AL for Landscape Architect, A1/A2 for multiple architectural firms) and an eight-character element field.  The element field comprises a mandatory four-character main element code and an optional four-character sub-element code.  Standard main element codes are listed in Annex A, and recommended sub-element codes are in Annex B.  While adherence to these standards is encouraged for industry consistency, user-defined codes are permissible for internal use if documented and communicated effectively within the project team.  If no sub-element is needed, "----" is used. Table 3 provides examples.  The document is licensed for single-user access only.

CP 83 Part 1 (2004, 2015) defines standard element names for consistency in the construction industry.  Annex A lists mandatory main element names alphabetically, while Annex B provides recommended sub-element names.  Users can create custom elements for internal use, but these must be documented and communicated clearly within the project.  A 4-character abbreviation convention (generally truncating vowels and keeping first/last characters) is suggested for element names.  The "Presentation field" uses one or two alphanumeric characters to define the format of information, with the first character having two classification levels (basic and unspecified).

elements.text: 4.4.3 Presentation field
elements.summary: The "Presentation field" within this standard defines the format or type of information, using one or two alphanumeric characters.  The first character provides a basic classification: 1) Element graphics, 2) Annotation, 3) Model (combined element and annotation), or 4) Paper/Page information.

elements.text: T he Presentation field represents the format or type of information presented and is denoted by one(1) or two (2) alphanumeric characters.
elements.summary: The "Presentation field" defines the format/type of information displayed using one or two alphanumeric characters.

elements.text: 4 .4.3.1 First character
elements.summary: The first character of the Presentation field in CP 83 Part 1: 2004 (2015) classifies the format of information.  It denotes the basic classification (element graphics, annotation, model, or paper/page information) and may further classify annotations (text, hatching, dimension, marking).

elements.text: T here are two levels of classification in the first character field:
elements.summary: The first character of the Presentation field in CP 83: Part 1 (2004) (2015) has two classification levels.  The first level broadly categorizes information as Element graphics, Annotation, Model (combined elements and annotation), or Paper/Page information.  The second level provides further detail, classifying Annotations into Text, Hatching, Dimension, and Marking, and classifying Paper/Page information into Border, Tabular information, Notes, Legends, Schedules, and Diagrams.

elements.text: a ) Basic classification
elements.summary: CP 83 defines the "Presentation" field with a one or two alphanumeric character code. The first character provides a basic classification of the information:  Element graphics, Annotation, Model (combined elements and annotations), or Paper/Page information.  Annotations can be further classified as text, hatching, dimensions, or markings. Paper/page information can be further classified as borders, tables, notes, legends, schedules, or diagrams.  Table 4 lists the valid codes.

It focuses on the "Presentation field," a one or two alphanumeric character code defining the format and type of information displayed. The first character provides a broad classification (Element graphics, Annotation, Model, or Paper/Page information), with further sub-classifications for Annotations (Text, Hatching, Dimension, Marking) and Paper/Page elements (Border, Tabular information, Notes, Legends, Schedules, Diagrams). pages.summary: This document excerpt from the Singapore Standard CP 83 : Part 1 : 2004 (2015), licensed by Enterprise Singapore, details layer naming conventions for AEC CAD projects, specifically for Addition and Alteration (A&A) works.  The standard defines a structured layer name comprising fields for Originator, Element (with main and sub-element designations), Presentation (projection/view as detailed in Table 5, e.g., "F" for front view), an optional Status (for A&A tracking, using codes from Table 6, e.g., "N" for new), and a User-defined field.  Figure 2 illustrates this structure with the example "A-_WALLPARP_E-_N-", representing a new parapet wall (WALLPARP) designed by an architect (A-) displayed as element graphics (E-).  The standard emphasizes clear documentation and communication of these conventions, especially for user-defined fields and status codes, to ensure consistent understanding among project stakeholders.

elements.summary: The provided text excerpt from CP 83: Part 1: 2004 (2015) describes a standardized layer naming convention for CAD files in the AEC industry.  This convention uses a structured format to convey information about the layer's originator, element type, presentation type, and status.  User-defined fields are permitted but require clear documentation and communication between project stakeholders.  The examples illustrate the structure, showing how codes denote the originating discipline (e.g., A- for Architect), the element being represented (e.g., WALLPARP for parapet wall), the presentation type (e.g., E- for element graphics, I- for tabulated information), and the status (e.g., N- for new work).  This standardized approach facilitates better organization, collaboration, and understanding of CAD drawings.

pages.summary: This page details the standardized CAD layer naming convention from CP 83: Part 1: 2004 (2015) for AEC projects.  The convention uses a structured `Originator_Element_Presentation_Status` format to improve drawing organization and interdisciplinary collaboration.  The *Originator* code identifies the discipline (e.g., A- for Architect, C- for Civil Engineer), the *Element* describes the object being represented (e.g., WALL, AREACALC, SDRNPIPE), the *Presentation* indicates the display type (e.g., E- for element graphics, I- for tabulated information, D- for dimensions), and the *Status* (optional) denotes the element's state (e.g., N- for new, R- for removal).  Numerous examples illustrate the convention's application across various disciplines and element types, emphasizing consistent and clear communication within the project.  While user-defined fields are permissible, they require thorough documentation and agreement among stakeholders.

Examples illustrate the convention's application. The text also notes that the main elements are listed alphabetically and references a Singapore standard (CP 83 : Part 1 : 2004 (2015)).
